document_title: Chondrogenesis and Mineralization During In Vitro Culture of Human Mesenchymal Stem Cells on Three-Dimensional Woven Scaffolds
summary_full: This study investigates the influence of culture duration and medium additives on the development of engineered tissues from human mesenchymal stem cells (hMSCs) on three-dimensional (3D) woven poly(É›-caprolactone) (PCL) scaffolds. hMSCs were cultured for 1, 21, or 45 days in either chondrogenic or osteogenic medium. Results showed that chondrogenic medium promoted the formation of cartilaginous tissue by day 21, with subsequent hypertrophic mineralization observed by day 45 at the interface between the engineered tissue and the scaffold. The composition, mechanical properties, and gene expression were significantly affected by both culture duration and medium type. Constructs cultured for 45 days in chondrogenic medium exhibited mechanical properties comparable to native articular cartilage. Gene expression analysis indicated sequential regulation of markers for chondrogenesis and endochondral bone formation. In contrast, osteogenic medium resulted in limited osteogenesis. These findings suggest that long-term culture on 3D scaffolds can induce chondrogenesis and regional mineralization, offering potential for osteochondral defect repair.
key_findings: Chondrogenic medium promotes cartilaginous tissue formation by day 21 and hypertrophic mineralization by day 45 in hMSC-seeded 3D PCL scaffolds.
45-day chondrogenic cultures achieved mechanical properties similar to native articular cartilage (aggregate modulus ~0.15 MPa).
Gene expression analysis revealed sequential regulation of chondrogenic (Sox-9, collagen type II, aggrecan) and endochondral ossification markers (Runx2, osteocalcin).
Mineralization occurred regionally at the interface between the engineered cartilage and the PCL scaffold after 45 days of chondrogenic culture.
Osteogenic medium resulted in significantly less extracellular matrix deposition and lower expression of cartilage-specific genes compared to chondrogenic medium.
future_research_fields: Optimizing cell seeding techniques for uniform distribution within scaffolds.
Investigating the role of oxygen gradients and pH in inducing site-specific tissue differentiation.
Evaluating the long-term mechanical properties of engineered tissues with varying scaffold degradation rates.
Assessing donor-to-donor variability in hMSC response for clinical translation.
Developing strategies for controlled, site-specific induction of bone formation alongside cartilage in osteochondral grafts.
conclusions: Culture duration and medium additives significantly influence the differentiation of hMSCs on 3D woven PCL scaffolds, leading to the formation of cartilaginous tissue with regional mineralization under chondrogenic conditions. These findings highlight the potential of this system for osteochondral defect repair, suggesting that long-term culture can promote a hypertrophic chondrocyte phenotype and subsequent mineralization.
impact_statement: This research provides insights into engineering osteochondral tissue constructs using mesenchymal stem cells and 3D scaffolds, offering a promising avenue for repairing cartilage and bone defects.
